docs.snippet: The two scientists from Djibouti came into the control room, their eyes wide with excitement. It was the heart, they were told, of the world's largest and most sensitive network for listening to the faint echoes of clandestine nuclear blasts.    T...
docs.lead_paragraph: The two scientists from Djibouti came into the control room, their eyes wide with excitement. It was the heart, they were told, of the world's largest and most sensitive network for listening to the faint echoes of clandestine nuclear blasts. The scientists were in Vienna for their inaugural tour of the facility and said they were pleased to be among the network's newest members. Their monitoring station in Djibouti, they said, will proudly join the 89 countries, 140 stations and 268 experts that now sift through the seismic din of earthquakes and volcanic eruptions for telltale signs of nuclear testing.
docs.abstract: Preparatory Commission for the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty Organization, global monitoring network, records seismic waves to try and track testing that violates eight-year-old United Nations-sponsored nuclear test ban; current involvement in commission includes 89 countries, 140 stations and 268 experts; scientists analyze data and look for signatures of nuclear blasts; network is also able to shed light on natural seismic events; Indian Ocean earthquake and subsequent tsunami was recorded by group; map; graph (M)

headline.main: Listening for Atom Blasts, But Hearing Earthquakes

docs.snippet: In recent months Iran has been heating up as a popular off-the-beaten path destination for globe-trotting Americans. Now several tour companies have had to cancel trips there because of visa complications related to President Donald Trump's travel...
docs.lead_paragraph: In recent months Iran has been heating up as a popular off-the-beaten path destination for globe-trotting Americans. Now several tour companies have had to cancel trips there because of visa complications related to President Donald Trump's travel ban.
